abstracts.cdata!:
The Taihu Basin Flood Control
            Project's outcome is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as highly likely, institutional development
            impact as substantial, Bank performance satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance as satisfactory. Key lessons learned
            from the project implementation include: There should be one
            Basic River Management Authority responsible for the overall
            planning and management of flood protection and water
            resources. Effective coordination with governments and
            government agencies is important to avoid project delays. If
            a flood control project involves substantial amount of land
            acquisition and resettlement, a well-prepared Resettlement
            Action Plan and Implementation Plan are prerequisites.
            Widening and deepening of major river channels by dredging
            involved disposal of large quantities of spoil materials
            dredged from the river channels. Suitable types of dredging
            machinery should be carefully reviewed and determined based
            on river conditions to ensure efficient performance of
            dredging work by contracts. Adequate and timely counterpart
            fund is critical. Procurement training by the Bank and the
            Basic Management Authority is important. A longer
            implementation period should be planned for if the project
            works cover wide area with large quantity of earthwork
            carried out under water in major river channels.
